title: Ceremonial daggers still major part of heritage
description:
(22 Sep 2017) LEADIN:
Ceremonial daggers are an ancient tradition that are still firmly part of Yemeni culture.
Known as Janbiyas, they take many weeks or months to make and are used at important celebrations.
STORYLINE:
The hammer expertly pounds the metal, crafting a dagger blade.
This man is one of hundreds of Yemenis working in the Janbiya or dagger industry.
In the old city in Sanaa, dozens of small shops manufacture and sell the Yemeni weapons.
A typical Janbiya has certain characteristics, including a hilt, a short curved blade made of steel with two cutting edges, and a scabbard fixed to a leather belt.
The daggers take a long time to manufacture - and the most prestigious type, called Saifani, take the most time of all.
Mohammed Al-Azizi, dagger maker, says standard Janbiyas take weeks or even months to produce.
"As for the expensive Saifani, it needs a very long time because it needs a brilliant mind, meaning mental concentration on the work."
Janbiya fan Khaled Dawood is shopping for his latest dagger.
He's negotiating the price with sellers.
Dawood believes the blades are a "symbol of manhood and chivalry".
He wants to buy a very old dagger that's more than 1,000 years old, but these items are very expensive.
In old Sanaa, shops selling Janbiyas are abundant, especially for old Janbiyas, many of which were made hundreds of years ago. 
Prices start from two million Yemeni riyals (10,000 US dollars), and the most expensive ones cost much more.
"A Janbiya is made of rhinoceros (horn) and is divided into several types, including the Saifani," says Abdu Mohammed, dagger seller.
He says the most expensive cost up to 50,000 dollars.
"The more it is liked and loved, the higher its price."
For Yemenis, the Janbiya is considered to be a part and parcel of Yemeni traditional wear. 
It's part of their heritage and during celebrations like Eid al-Adha, Yemeni men are sure to wear them and even dance with the daggers.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/162fe1fd391bfe2451d02e363732498e 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork
